On 1/10/07, Ole Ersoy <ole_ersoy@...> wrote:
> Just a comment on this part:
>
>
> >This one is not
> >even theoretically
> >possible for a machine to do.
>
> >For example, consider this method on a Triangle
> >class:
>
> > public boolean isIsosceles() {
> >     return a == b || a == c || b == c;
> > }
> >
>
> aInRange bInRange cInRange ExpectedReturnValue
>    2        2        2          true
>    2        2        3          true
>    2        3        3          true
>    3        2        2          true
>    3        3        2          true
>    3        3        3          true
>    1        2        3          false
>    3        2        1          false
>    2        3        1          false
>

> So these points represent the 100% test.

But the point that several other people have made is that it is
impossible for the machine to know whether these tests are correct. If
the code is wrong, the test will be wrong too.

Kevin
